newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power weaker amid lower BPA prices.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power weaker amid lower BPA prices.

text.p: October spot power prices in the western U.S. slipped Monday after Bonneville Power Administration decreased its prices for pre-scheduled power during peak-demand hours.
"They (BPA) came out more aggressively than we expected," said one cash power trader. "Daily prices were already down, but there has been on impact on October (cash prices)."
Market sources also said moderate weather conditions were capping regional demand.
Bonneville offered power between 1000 and 2100 PDT on Tuesday at $18.00 per megawatt hour (MWh), compared with $20.00 for similar hours on Monday.

Power at Palo Verde for October was quoted 16.30-16.70 per MWh, down from 16.50-16.70 on Friday. October California-Oregon border (COB) electricity was quoted $15.90-16.25, compared with 16.20-16.40 on Friday.
Next-day deliveries at COB were quoted $17.00-18.00, unchanged from Friday. Mid-Columbia prices were steady at $16.00-17.00.
Palo Verde daily prices were quoted $21.00-23.00, also little changed from Friday.
Recent weather forecasts calling for above-normal precipitation in the Northwest could put further downward pressure on spot prices, noted another trade source.
In California, utility sources said they are considering bringing idled natural gas-fired units back on line if northwest hydroelectric prices continue at current levels.
"Gas is still pretty inexpensive for us," said one utility trader. "It might be cheaper than paying $18.00" for spot power.
